This manual describes version &appversion; of the Synaptic Package Manager.
Feedback
To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the &app; or this manual, use the bug report system at Synaptic Web, contact the mailing list synaptic-devel@nongnu.org or join the IRC channel #synaptic on irc.freenode.org.
&legal;

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The software on your system is organizied in so called packages. The &app; is a graphical frontend to the apt package management system. It allows you to perform all actions of the command line tool apt-get in a graphical environment.

&app; provides the following main features:
Install, remove, configure, upgrade and downgrade single and multiple packages.
Upgrade your whole system.
Manage package repositories.
Search the list of known packages by name, description and other package properties.
Filter the list of shown packages by status, section, properties or tag.
Arrange listed packages by initial letter, status or tag.
View all available online documentation related to a package.

note.para: Root rights are required to apply changes to the package system.

sect1.para:
You can start &app; in the following ways:
GNOME Applications menu
Choose
System Tools Software .
KDE menu
Choose
Settings Software .
Command line
To start &app; from a command line type the following , then press Return:
synaptic

caution.para: You can render your system unusable.

sect2.title: Overview
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed.

row.entry: Contains menus that provide access to all functions of &app; to you.
Provides direct access to the main functions refresh, system upgrade, apply and find.
Lists all known packages. The list can be narrowed down using filters.
Provides information about a selected package.

sect2.title: Toolbar
sect2.para: The toolbar provides access to the main actions and a quick search for packages.

textobject.phrase: Shows the toolbar of the &app; main window

listitem.para: Queries all repositories and rebuild the list of known packages.
Marks all available upgrades.
Applies all marked changes.

sect2.title: Package List
sect2.para: The package list shows all known packages by default. You can apply filters to narrow down the list of shown packages, see .

textobject.phrase: Shows the package list in the &app; main window.

sect2.para: To arrange the packages, you can choose the following modes from the View menu:

row.entry: Groups the packages by their initial name letter.
Groups the packages by their section, e.g. "admin", "base", "gnome", etc.
Groups the packages by their status, e.g. "installed", "not installed", "obsolete" etc.
Debian only: Groups the packages by their tag. Tags are keywords provided by third parity. For further instructions and help see the documentation of dwww.

sect2.para: The column order and the used colours can be changed in the preferences.

sect2.title: Package Details
sect2.para: The package details area provides information about the selected package and also controls to modify the status, e.g. mark a package for installation.

textobject.phrase: Shows the package details area in the &app; main window.

sect2.para:
The notebook exists of the following tabs:
Tabs of the details notebook
Tab
Description
Common
Shows basic information of the package: name, short description, maintainer, status, priority, tags (if supported) and version.
Description
Shows a long description of the package.
Dependencies
Lists required, depending, provided, suggested and recommended packages.
Installed files
Lists all installed files of the package.
Expert
Allows to override the default version selection of &app;.

varlistentry.term: To find a package in the list of packages

listitem.para:
Type the name or a part of it into the
located in the toolbar. &app; will automatically jump to the next matching package in the list.
To find the next matching package press the the forward button next to the find field.
To begin the search again from the beginning of the package list click on the upward button.
Open the search dialog Package Find... from the menu or press Ctrl F.
Type the search expression into the find field, e.g. "mp3 ogg player".
Select the fields that you want to search in, e.g. name and description.
Click on Find to start the search. In our example only music players and related packages will be listed.

sect2.title: To Install Packages
sect2.para: To install one or more packages perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
Refresh the package list to be aware of the latest available version:
Choose Actions Refresh Package List from the menu.
Click on Refresh List in the toolbar.
Press the key combination CtrlR.
Select the package that you wish to install in the with a left mouse click. To select further packages hold down the Ctrl key while left clicking on the additional packages.

Mark the selected packages for installation:
Click on Install in the package control area.
Choose Package Install from the menu.
Right click on the package and choose Install from the context menu.
Press the key combination CtrlI.

Apply the marked changes to actually install the package(s):
Click on Apply in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Apply Marked Changes from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlP.

sect2.title: To Remove Packages

note.para: Configuration files and user created data (e.g. a website in /var/www) are not removed from the system by default.
Debian only: This behavior can be changed in the preferences.
Debian only: To remove all files related to the package choose Remove Including Configuration instead of Remove.

Debian only: To also remove packages that are only installed as dependency of the to be removed package(s) and that would be no longer needed (orphaned) afterwards, choose Remove Including Orphaned Dependecies instead of Remove.

sect2.para: To remove one or more packages follow these steps:

listitem.para: Select the package that you wish to remove in the with a left click. To select further packages hold down the Ctrl key while left clicking on additional packages.

Mark the selected package(s) for removal:
Click on Remove in the package control area.
Choose Package Remove from the menu.
Right click on the package and choose Remove from the context menu.
Press the key Delete.

Apply the marked changes to actually remove the package(s):
Click on Apply in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Apply Marked Changes from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlP.

sect2.title: To Upgrade Packages
sect2.para: To upgrade one or more packages follow these steps:

listitem.para:
Refresh the package list, to get aware of the latest available version:
Choose Actions Refresh Package List from the menu.
Click on Refresh List in the toolbar.
Press the key combination CtrlR.
Select the package that you wish to upgrade in the . To select further packages hold down the Ctrl key while left clicking on additional packages.

Mark the selected packages for upgrade:
Click on Upgrade in the package control area.
Choose Package Upgrade from the menu.
Right click on the package and choose Upgrade from the context menu.
Press the key combination CtrlU.

Apply the marked changes to actually upgrade the package(s):
Click on Apply in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Apply Marked Changes from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlP.

tip.para: To perform all available upgrade at once, see .

sect2.title: To Upgrade the Whole System
sect2.para: The system upgrade enables you to upgrade your system to the latest version without having to mark each package upgrade manually.

&app; provides two system upgrade methods:
Default upgrade
The default upgrade method marks upgrades of installed packages only. If the upgrade would depend on not installed packages or conflict with an already installed package, the upgrade will not be marked.
Smart upgrade (Dist-Upgrade)
The smart upgrade method tries to resolve package conflicts intelligently. This includes installing additional required packages and prefering packages with higher priority.

note.para: Upgrades to a later major release of the operating system have to be done with the dist-upgrade method, e.g. from Conectiva 9 to Conectiva 10 or from Debian Woody 3.0 to Debian Sarge 4.0.

sect2.para: To upgrade your system follow these steps:

listitem.para:
Refresh the package list to be aware of the latest available package versions:
Choose Actions Refresh Package List from the menu.
Click on Refresh List in the toolbar.
Press the key combination CtrlR.

Mark all available upgrades:
Click on Upgrade System in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Upgrade System from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlG.
Choose the upgrade method. Smart upgrade (dist-upgrade) is recommended.

Apply the marked changes to actually upgrade the system:
Click on Apply in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Apply Marked Changes from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlP.

tip.para: You can change the default upgrade method in the preferences.

sect2.title: To Downgrade Packages

caution.para: This may render your package system unusable!

Downgrading packages is a broken feature, since apt and &app; can only handle conflicts and dependency resolution of upgrades. You may find this feature helpful in some rare circumstances, but it is not recommended to use.

sect2.para: To downgrade a package you have to select a specific version of the package:

listitem.para: Select the package that you wish to downgrade in the .
Open the Expert tab in the details area.
Choose the version to be installed from the list.

Apply the marked changes to actually downgrade the package(s):
Click on Apply in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Apply Marked Changes from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlP.

sect2.title: To Apply Marked Changes
sect2.para:
To apply all marked changes perform one of the following instructions:
Click on Apply in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Apply Marked Changes from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlP.

tip.para: To list only marked packages apply the "Queued Changes" filter.

sect2.title: To Undo Marked Changes
sect2.para: The following ways allow you to unmark changes:

listitem.para: Right click on the package and choose No Changes from the context menu.
Select the package with a left mouse click and choose No Changes from the package control. To select further packages hold down the Ctrl key while left clicking on the additional package.
Select the package(s) and press Ctrl N.
Choose Actions Clear All Queued Changes from the menu.

varlistentry.term: To undo the last marking action

listitem.para: Choose Actions Undo from the menu.

sect2.title: To Configure Packages

note.para: Debian only: This feature requires the installation of libgnome2-perl.

sect2.para: Debian provides a unified method, called debconf, to configure software packages. This feature is not supported by all packages. If a package supports this feautre, the configuration can be done through an assistant.

To configure a supported package:
Select the package that you wish to configure in the .
Click on Configure in the package control.

tip.para: To list only configurable packages apply the Configurable Packages filter.

sect2.title: To View Package Documentation

note.para: Debian only: This feature requires the installation of dwww.

sect2.para:
To view all available documentation related to a package in a web browser you have to:
Select the package in the .
Click on Documentation in the package control.

sect2.title: To Fix Broken Packages
sect2.para: Misleading dependency properties or errors during the installation of packages can break the dependency structure.
&app; will not allow any further changes to the system untill all broken packages are fixed.
To correct the broken packages choose Actions Fix Broken Packages from the menu.

tip.para: To list only broken packages apply the Broken filter.

sect1.title: Repositories
sect1.para: Packages are made available through so called repositories. The index of the repository provides basic information about all available packages, e.g. required dependencies or a short description. &app; merges all index files to a single .
Repositories can be located on many medias: CD-Rom/DVD, local hard disk, internet (http, ftp) or remote file system (nfs).

sect2.title: To Refresh the Package List
sect2.para:
To refresh and rebuild the list of known packages:
Choose Actions Refresh Package List from the menu.
Click on Refresh List in the toolbar.

sect2.title: To Add, Remove or Edit Repositories
sect2.para: You can edit, add or remove repositories in the repository preferences:
Choose Preferences Repositories from the menu.

sect1.title: Filters
sect1.para: Filters enable you to narrow down the list of shown packages.
&app; comes with a set of predefined filters:

row.entry: Lists only currently not installed packages.
Lists only packages with a later version available.
Lists only packages with broken dependencies.
Lists only new packages since the last refresh.
Lists only former installed packages that left data or configuration files on the system.
Lists only packages that can be configured through the debian package configuration system (debconf).
Lists only packages that are not (for longer) included in one of the specified repositories.
Lists only matching packages of the last package search, see .

sect2.title: To Apply Filters
sect2.para: To apply a filter perform one of the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose the filter from the ViewApply Filter menu.
Choose the filter from the Show combobox in the main window.

sect2.title: To Edit, Remove or Add Filters
sect2.para: Filters can be added, removed and modified in the filter preferences:

listitem.para: Choose from the menu View Edit Filters....
Click on Filters... in the main window.

row.entry: Use a locale supported by Xlib.

sect1.para: List of all global short cuts in &app;:
